 REASONS FOR DECISION 
Introduction  [1] These are the reasons for the decision in the appeal, pursuant to subsection 63(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
 (IRPA ) of TXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX (the principal appellant), his wife, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX (the appellant) and EXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX (the minor appellant).  They are appealing the de termination by the Minister’s Delegate, made on September 27, 2006, to issue a departure orders against them as a persons described in subsection 41(b) of IRPA
, because the Minister’s Delegate was satisfied, on a balance of probabilities, there were grounds to believe that  the appellants were permanent residents who were inadmissible to Canada for failing to comp ly with the residency obligation contained in section 28 of IRPA
.     [2] Specifically, the appellants had failed to reside in Canada for at least 730 days in the five- year period immediately after they became permanent residents, which was on March 27, 2003. The Minister’s Delegate ...

 ORAL REASONS FOR DECISION  
[1] These are the reasons for the decision in the appeal s of XXXXXXXXXXXXXX and 
XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX  (the appellants) , who appeal ed from a determin ation that they breached the 
residency obligation.  
ISSUE  
[2] The five -year period under consideration is from July 5, 2010 to July 5, 2015. The parties 
agreed that the appellants were in the country for only 249 days during the five -year period. This 
is only 34 percent compliance. The visa officer’s determination is legally valid . T he appellants 
are asking f or special relief on humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds.

 RAD File No. / N° de dossier de la S AR :  
 
  
REASONS FOR DECISION  
[1] XXXX XXXX  (the Appellant) is a citizen of Saint Lucia. She appeals a decision of the 
Refugee Protection Division (RPD) denying her claim for refugee protection. The Appellant asks 
the Refugee Appeal Division (RAD) to set aside the decision of the RPD, and find the Appellant 
to be a Convention refugee, or in the alternative, refer the claim back to the RPD for 
redetermination. The Appellant asks for a hearing to deal with the documentation presented in the 
Memorandum of Appeal. No new evidence was presented in the Me morandum of Appeal.  
DETERMINATION  
[2] Pursuant to ss. 111(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act  (IRPA), the RAD 
confirms the determination of the RPD and dismisses the appeal.  
Background  
[3] The Appellant  was raised by her stepmother, and does not ha ve any knowledge of her 
biological mother.  The Appellant  discovered during her teenage years that she was more attracted 
to girls than boys.  As a result of the ...

1 REASONS FOR DECISION 
 [1] XXXXXXXXXXXXXX, her husband XXXXXXXXXXXXX,  and their sons XXXXXXXXXXX and XXXXXXXXXXX (the “appellants”) appeal the departure or ders issued against each one of them by the Member of the Immigration Division (the “ID” ) of the Immigration and Refugee Board (the “IRB”) on September 3, 2010, because they were found to be persons described in the subsection 27(2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (the “Act”),
1 and therefore, they were inadmissible under subsection 41(b) of the Act.  [2] Section 318 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations  (the “Regulations”)
2 provides that any terms and conditions imposed under the former Immigration Act,
3 become terms and conditions under the present Act, which came into force in June 2002.  [3] The appeals are made pursuant to subsection 63(3)

  [1] XXXXXXXXXXX, the principal claimant (PC), is a citizen of the Republic of Haiti (Haiti) who seeks refugee protection pursu ant to subsections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
1 (IRPA). The claim of her daughter, XXXXXXXXXXX, the minor claimant, was joined pursuant to Rule 49.1.
2  The panel appointed the XX as the Designated Representative (DR) of the minor claimant. Allegations [2] The PC alleges that she joined the polit ical party Organisation du Peuple en Lutte (OPL). She alleges that on XXXXX 1997, a bu llet entered her home, which prompted her to go into hiding. She travelled with her daught er to the USA in XXXXX 1997.  She claims to have made an asylum claim which was late r refused. She made a claim for protection in Canada in XXXXX 2007. She claims a well -founded fear of persecution for reason of her political opinion and her membership in  a particular social group, namely her gender. [3] The minor claimant has French nationalit y by virtue of her birth at XXXXX XXXXX. The PC did not advance any evidence of perse cution or personalized risk for the minor claimant in her country of nationality. Issues and Determination [4] ...

  [1] XXXXXXXXXXX, the principal claimant (PC), is a citizen of the Republic of Haiti (Haiti) who seeks refugee protection pursu ant to subsections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
1 (IRPA). The claim of her daughter, XXXXXXXXXXX, the minor claimant, was joined pursuant to Rule 49.1.
2  The panel appointed the XX as the Designated Representative (DR) of the minor claimant. Allegations [2] The PC alleges that she joined the polit ical party Organisation du Peuple en Lutte (OPL). She alleges that on XXXXX 1997, a bu llet entered her home, which prompted her to go into hiding. She travelled with her daught er to the USA in XXXXX 1997.  She claims to have made an asylum claim which was late r refused. She made a claim for protection in Canada in XXXXX 2007. She claims a well -founded fear of persecution for reason of her political opinion and her membership in  a particular social group, namely her gender. [3] The minor claimant has French nationalit y by virtue of her birth at XXXXX XXXXX. The PC did not advance any evidence of perse cution or personalized risk for the minor claimant in her country of nationality. Issues and Determination [4] ...

[1] XXXXXXXXX  (the principal claimant) and his wife XXXXXXXXX , citizens of Syria, claim 
refugee protection pursuant to Section s 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection 
Act1 (IRPA).  
Background and Allegations  
[2] The specifics of the claim are set out in the narrative to the claimants’ Personal Information 
Forms2 (PIFs); the following is a summary.  
[3] The claimants have a son who has been granted refugee status in Canada.  In 2008 they 
attempted to come to Canada to visit that son, but were denied visitor visas since immigration 
officials were not convinced they would return to Syria.3  They were successful in obtaining vis itor 
visas in 2010, and arrived in Canada in XXXX  of that year.  The following month they filed claims 
for refugee protection.  They claim that they are of Kurdish ethnicity, and that their two politically -
active sons were persecuted by the authorities bef ore fleeing the country.  The intelligence service 
allegedly detained and abused the principal claimant because they sought his sons.  The claimants 
fear that, if returned to Syria, they will be harmed ...

IAD File No. / N° de dossier de la SAI : VB1 -02935  
 
 REASONS FOR DECISION  
 
[1] These are the reasons and decision of the Immigration Appeal Division (the “IAD”) 
pertaining to the appeal  filed pursuant to subsection 63(1) of the Immigration and Refugee 
Protection Act  (the “ Act ”)1 made by XXXXXXXXXXX (the “appellant”), from the refusal of the 
sponsorship application for a permanent resident visa of her spouse, JamXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX 
(the  “applicant”) from Afghanistan.  
 
[2] The application was refused under subsection 4(1) of the Immigration and Refugee 
Protection Regulations  (the “ Regulations ”)2 and subsection 16(1) of the Act . The details of the 
refusal are set out in the refusal letter and C AIPS3 notes of the immigration officer.4 
 
BACKGROUND  
 
[3] The appellant is 52 years old and was landed in Canada in April 1984. The applicant is 37 
years old and lives in Afghanistan. The appellant and applicant were married on May 12, 2009.5  
 
ANALYSIS  
 
[4] Two t ests may be applied in order to disqualify a spouse under subsection 4(1) of the 
Regulations.  Only on...

 REASONS FOR DECISION  
 
[1] These are my reasons and decision in the appeal of XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX (the 
“appellan t”). The appeal is from a refusal to approve the permanent resident visa applications 
made by SylXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX and JaXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX  (the “applicants”) who 
were sponsored by the appellant. Those are the appellant's biological parents.  
 
[2] The abili ty to sponsor family members is permitted by sections 12 and 13 of the 
Immigra tion and Refugee Protection Act (the “ Act ”).1 Eligibility to sponsor requires 
demonstration of income at, or above,  income levels that are set by the Immigration and Refugee 
Prot ection R egulation s (the “ Regulations ”).2  
 
[3] This application was refused based on an assessment of income from December 2012, to 
December 2013, for five persons. At that time, the sponsor had to show income at, or above, the 
levels estab...

 REASONS FOR DECISION  
INTRODUCTION  
[1] XXXX XXXX  and XXXX XXXX  are citizens of Russia who are seeking refugee 
protection pursuant to sections 96 and 97(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act 
(IRPA).1 
ALLEGATIONS  
[2] The specifics of the claim are set out in the narrative to the principal claimant’s Personal 
Information Form (PIF);2 the follow ing is a summary.  
[3] The principal claimant (PC) worked in a company that XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  
XXXX .  In XXXX  2012 , a number of managerial people left the company and the PC became a 
XXXX XXXX .  The PC was pressured by the deputy director of the company, XXXX , to get his 
workers to commit unlawful acts such as altering the fiscal memory of the XXXX XXXX . The 
PC resisted this pressure.  He wrote to the main office to describe what had happened.  There was 
a meeting with the director, XXXX , on XXXX XXXX , 2012 in  which the director expressed his 
disapproval of the PC ’s manager, after which XXXX  was fired.  The PC then had a meeting with 
the director and the new deputy director.  At this meeting the PC wa...
